title: Tradeoff between avoiding false positives and false negatives
content: For any test, there is usually a tradeoff between avoiding false positives and false negatives. The higher the sensitivity, the lower the specificity. The higher the specificity, the lower the sensitivity.

title: High sensitivity vs low sensitivity
content: High sensitivity test is more likely to detect cancer when cancer is truly present and less likely to miss cancer when cancer is truly present. Low sensitivity test is less likely to detect cancer when cancer is truly present and more likely to miss cancer when cancer is truly present.

title: High specificity vs low specificity
content: High specificity test is more likely to not detect cancer when cancer is truly not present and less likely to detect cancer when cancer is truly not present (i.e., fewer false alarms). Low specificity test has a lower proportion of negatives that are correctly identified as such and is more likely to detect cancer when cancer is truly not present (i.e., more false alarms).

title: Positive predictive value and negative predictive value
content: Positive predictive value: Positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease. Negative predictive value: Negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly do not have the disease.

title: Example of thyroid cancer screening
content: Here’s an example: 500,000 people are screened for thyroid cancer with a population prevalence of 0.16%. The screening tool used is ultrasound with 98% sensitivity and 54% specificity. We can see from this example that the NPV is virtually 100%. We can also see that even with a high sensitivity, which tells us the true positive rate, the PPV is a remarkably low 0.3%.

title: Example of breast cancer screening
content: Here’s a different example: 500,000 women are screened for breast cancer with a population prevalence of 11%. The screening tool used is Prenuvo MRI with 92% sensitivity and 99.6% specificity. The NPV is 99%. The PPV in this example is 96.6%.

title: Sensitivity and Specificity
content: Sensitivity, specificity, PPV, and NPV shouldn’t be judged in isolation. Therefore, a test with 100% sensitivity can be completely useless in practice without considering specificity. The converse is true as well. The test would have 100% specificity. But it would also carry with it 0% sensitivity.

title: PPV and Prevalence
content: Similarly, in the positive-letter example, 100% sensitivity may be misleading in terms of its ability to predict someone has cancer. If the population prevalence was 0.5%, the PPV would also be 0.5%, meaning the test is no better than, well, sending random letters to postal addresses. The same holds true for the negative-letter example.

title: Diagnostic Measures
content: Diagnostic measures help us determine if our screening tools are effective at detecting when cancer is present or not.

title: Misleading Measures
content: Often, these measures can be misleading, especially when evaluated in isolation.

title: Context is Key
content: It’s important to look at diagnostics in context.
